title: 108_hr135
content: The "Twenty-First Century Water Commission Act of 2003" establishes a commission to address the increasing stress on the nation's water resources and develop strategies to ensure safe and sustainable water supplies. The Commission's duties include conducting water assessments, studying water management programs, and developing recommendations for a comprehensive water strategy that respects States' roles in regulating water rights and identifies incentives for water conservation. The Commission's duties include identifying incentives for water conservation, optimizing water supply reliability, and suggesting financing options for water management projects. The Commission's duties include identifying incentives for water conservation, optimizing water supply reliability, suggesting financing options for water management projects, and strategies to conserve existing water supplies. Other objectives related to effective water supply management are also included. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The President appoints 5 members, the Speaker of the House appoints 2 members, and the Majority Leader of the Senate appoints 2 members. Members must have expertise in water policy and cannot hold any other position in the government while serving on the Commission. The Commission members, appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, represent diverse regional perspectives. The President designates the Chairperson, and members serve for the Commission's lifespan. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members receive travel expenses. The Commission members receive travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, in accordance with applicable provisions under subchapter I of chapter 57, United States Code. SEC. 6. MEETINGS AND QUORUM. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed and additional meetings as needed. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for conducting business. SEC. 7. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Director of the Commission is appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Majority Leader of the Senate, in consultation with relevant committees. The Director and staff will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission's powers and proceedings are outlined in Section 8. The Commission shall hold at least 10 hearings, including one in Washington, D.C., and others in different regions of the U.S. to gather diverse testimony on water issues. Federal agencies must provide information and support upon request within 30 days. The Commission must provide necessary information within 30 days of request and assign personnel on a reimbursable basis to carry out the provisions of the Act. SEC. 9. REPORTS. The Commission is required to submit interim reports every 6 months detailing its progress to the President and relevant congressional committees. A final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation must be submitted within 3 years of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission is mandated to submit findings and conclusions to the President and specific congressional committees. The Commission will terminate within 30 days of transmitting the final report. $9,000,000 is authorized for the implementation of this Act.
